awd_titl_txt: Evaluating a Role-Playing Approach to Improve Transferable Professional Communication Skills of Chemical Engineering Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by implementing evidence-based practices in technical communication instruction in laboratory courses that are standard in chemical engineering curriculum. This will be done by incorporating industry-based role-playing scenarios into the courses. Student tutors trained specifically for technical writing will also be used in the courses. The impact these interventions have on the students’ communication skills will be evaluated. Comparisons to the expectations of practicing engineers in industry will be made. By using role-playing scenarios relevant to the workplace, it is anticipated that the students will be more engaged in the course, recognize the value of communication to their future careers, and improve their communication skills. The skills the undergraduates learn will be transferable to their future careers as engineers in industry or researchers in graduate school. Collaboration with communication experts through the institution’s Writing Center will provide more effective teaching and evaluation of communication skills. This project will benefit society by improving STEM education and providing chemical engineering undergraduates technical communication skills to be competitive in the STEM workforce.

Professional skills such as communication are highly valued in engineering practice and yet are a challenge to incorporate effectively into the chemical engineering curriculum. With this project, unit operation laboratory courses will be improved by implementing evidence-based practices in technical communication instruction in the curriculum. Three research questions will be explored: (i) how do expectations of “good” technical communication differ between instructors and practicing chemical engineers?; (ii) how do technical communications skills of students improve with use of industrially relevant role-playing scenarios and embedded trained tutors?; and (iii) what is the correlation between student writing self-efficacy and technical communication skills? As part of the research, rubrics will be developed and validated to assess technical communication skills, and industry partners will assess student technical writing and rubrics to reflect the needs of industry. Role-playing scenarios relevant to industrial, research, and academic careers will be implemented, and Writing Center tutors will provide technical writing support to students. In order to make clear the relationship between writing self-efficacy and technical communication skills before and after the intervention, surveys will be given to the students and analyzed for correlations. The results of this project have the potential to be applied in laboratory courses across many disciplines and levels of undergraduate curriculum. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Technical communication is highly valued in the engineering workplace, and proficiency in this area has been linked to career advancement. However, many engineering graduates often lack the necessary skills to be competitive in the workforce. Despite the importance of communication skills, effective integration into the engineering curriculum can be challenging and students often do not recognize the significance of the technical communication work they do as an undergraduate to their future careers. In addition, the engineering communication landscape is continually evolving due to rapid change in technology and industry practices. Therefore, courses that integrate communication skills into the engineering curriculum need to remain current with the skills students need. Laboratory courses standard to chemical engineering curriculums are typically where chemical engineering students develop professional skills in experimental design and analysis, teamwork, and communication. However, engineering labs historically can be formulaic, closed-ended, and seemingly irrelevant to students' future careers, which negatively impacts student engagement. Additionally, engineering instructors may lack formal training in communication instruction and assessment, which can be made more difficult if multiple instructors are grading within a course. As such, effective feedback and assessment, including consistent grading, can be an issue.

In this project, a two-part series of senior level chemical engineering laboratory courses were redesigned to simulate a real world industrial environment. To situate the course activities in the context of engineers practicing in industry, a scenario was created where students enrolled in the courses were interns in the first semester and new employees during the second semester working at a consulting firm. By embedding students in scenarios that mimic industry practices, we aimed to demonstrate the relevancy of the coursework to their future careers, thereby increasing engagement. Using feedback solicited from practicing chemical engineers, assignments were designed to target specific technical communication skills transferable to the modern workplace. With this feedback, it was found that the communication standards of engineers in industry were largely in alignment with those of chemical engineering instructors, showing that assessment of the quality of student work in the academic context will be transferable to the expectations of new engineers in the engineering practice context.

To improve instructional effectiveness, student learning, and student skill development within the scenario, communication skills training workshops were developed in collaboration with communication experts at the university's Writing Center. Engineering specific Writing Center student tutors also provided one-on-one and group writing support. In addition, rubrics were developed to assess student proficiency in technical and communication skills relevant to the workforce.

The process of soliciting feedback from practicing engineers could be used to aid adaptation of the course design to other contexts and to continue modernizing engineering curricula. A major outcome of the project is the course design, as well as rubrics, that could be adopted in chemical engineering curriculums nationally and adapted for use in engineering laboratory courses for other disciplines. Grading using the developed rubrics that were disseminated through a local workshop and in a publication, was found to be consistent regardless of instructor, making them reliable for assessing engineering specific technical and communication skills. A major finding of this research was that students' writerly self-efficacy increased, indicating that the students feel more capable in their communication skills over the period of enrollment in these courses.
